text: But the biggest surprise emerged from decades of study of the genomes of host organisms.

Human genomes show evidence of much genetic material arising from viral genomes that integrated As much as half of the human genome may have arisen from essential for early development of human embryos.
Many human pathogens, such as Staphylococcus aureus, contain prophages encoding toxins.
Many host cell traits turn out to be expressed by integrated viral genomes, or prophages, that actually confer benefits on their host.
Early in the twentieth century, American cancer researcher Peyton Rous (1879–1970) discovered that some avian viruses cause tumors.
For this discovery, Rous won the 1966 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.
For example, Nostoc cyanobacteria possess a prophage that encodes nitrogenase, an enzyme for nitrogen fixation.
The tumor generation results from integration of a viral genome.
Bacteriophage lambda is discussed at length in Chapter 11.
In the showed evidence of phage gene expression from within host genomes.
How were integrated viral genomes discovered?
